The honey sample HMF content was determined based on the ability of UV absorbance of HMF at 284 nm according to the harmonized Methods of International Honey Commission ( Bogdanov, 2009). For the purpose, the difference between the absorbance of aqueous honey solution and the solution after the addition of bisulphate was determined to eliminate the intrusion of other components at the same wavelength. Then, HMF was calculated after subtracting the background absorbance at 336 nm. Subsequently, a spectrophotometer working in a wavelength range of 284 nm–336 nm was employed.
